choices.text: Most are asymptomatic and can be managed expectantly
Presence of submucosal fibroids decreases fertility and removing them can increase fertility
They are benign polyclonal tumors of the smooth muscle cells of the myometrium
Estrogen and progesterone appear to promote the development of fibroids

questions.text: Identify the incorrect statement regarding uterine fibroids:
questions.solution:
Fibroids are benign, monoclonal (and not polyclonal) tumors of the smooth muscle cells of the myometrium and contain large aggregations of extracellular matrix composed of collagen, elastin, fibronectin, and proteoglycan.

OPTION A: Fibroids are very common; most are asymptomatic and can be managed expectantly

OPTION B: The presence of submucosal fibroids decreases fertility and removing them can increase fertility; subserosal fibroids do not affect fertility and removing them does not increase fertility; intramural fibroids may slightly decrease fertility, but removal does not increase fertility.

OPTION D: Estrogen and progesterone appear to promote the development of fibroids. Fibroids are rarely observed before puberty, are most prevalent during the reproductive years, and regress after menopause. Factors that increase overall lifetime exposure to estrogen, such as obesity and early menarche, increase the incidence. Decreased exposure to estrogen found with smoking, exercise, and increased parity is protective. Progesterone is important in the pathogenesis of fibroids, which have increased concentrations of progesterone receptors A and B compared with normal myometrium.

KEY TAKEAWAY:

Fibroids develop from a single mutated smooth muscle cell in the uterus that begins to proliferate abnormally.

Genetic Mutation:

  • The mutation in the original cell leads to clonal expansion, where this single cell and its progeny multiply to form a benign tumor (fibroid).
  • Common genetic alterations in fibroids include rearrangements in chromosomes 12 and 14, and mutations in genes like MED12.

questions.text: Identify the following procedure performed for reduction in the growth of uterine leiomyomas:
questions.solution:
OPTION A: Radiofrequency Ablation (RFA) uses high-frequency electrical energy to generate heat, which is applied to the fibroid tissue. The heat causes the fibroid cells to shrink and die.

Technique: The procedure is often performed laparoscopically or via a transvaginal approach. A specialized needle-like probe is inserted into the fibroid under ultrasound or MRI guidance. The probe delivers the radiofrequency energy, targeting the fibroid.

OPTION B: MRgFUS uses high-intensity focused ultrasound waves to generate heat and ablate (destroy) the fibroid tissue. The procedure is guided by magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), which allows precise targeting and monitoring of the treatment area.

Technique: The patient lies inside an MRI scanner, and the focused ultrasound energy is delivered through the skin, targeting the fibroid tissue without the need for any incisions.

OPTION C: Uterine Artery Embolization (UAE) is a minimally invasive procedure used to treat symptomatic uterine fibroids by cutting off their blood supply, leading to their shrinkage and symptom relief. UAE involves injecting small particles (embolic agents) into the arteries supplying the fibroids. These particles block the blood flow to the fibroids, causing them to shrink over time due to lack of oxygen and nutrients.

OPTION D: HIFU (High Intensity Focussed Ultrasound) uses high-intensity focused ultrasound waves to generate localized heat in the fibroid tissue, causing thermal ablation (destruction) of the fibroid cells without affecting surrounding tissues.

KEY TAKEAWAY:

UAE works by blocking the blood supply to fibroids, causing them to shrink and lose their "feast" on blood flow.

Reference: www.researchgate.com

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman with symptomatic fibroids is scheduled for Uterine Artery Embolization (UAE). Which of the following is a potential complication of this procedure?
questions.solution:
OPTION C- Ovarian failure is a potential complication of UAE, especially in women over the age of 45, due to the reduced blood supply to the ovaries during the procedure.

KEY TAKEAWAY: Complications of UAE

questions.text: Identify the following instrument?
questions.solution:
Bonney's clamp is used in myomectomy, It curtails the blood supply to the uterus temporarily thereby minimising the blood loss during operation.

OPTION A: The Doyen Myoma Screw is a specialized instrument that features a screw-like design. This allows it to grip and hold myomas securely, making them easier to remove during myomectomy.

OPTION B: Shirodkar's uterus holding forceps is Used to extract tissue, tumors, or polyps from the uterus by elevating the vaginal wall. The clamps at the end of the ring handles feature serrated jaws to firmly grasp the tissue to be removed. The clamps are curved to the side to optimize visualization during procedures.

OPTION D: Green-Armytage forceps are used to grasp and clamp tissue in the uterus. The forceps has wide blades with horizontal serrations. the forceps are used for edges of the transverse incision in the lower segment.

KEY TAKEAWAY: Bonney's clamp is used in myomectomy, It curtails the blood supply to the uterus temporarily thereby minimising the blood loss during operation.

William Francis Victor Bonney was a prominent British gynaecological surgeon. His wife Annie suffered from very heavy periods which in turn resulted in severe anaemia and was corrected by a hysterectomy, thus preventing her having children. This setback led to Bonney's lifelong advocacy for the more conservative surgery of myomectomy over the more radical hysterectomy.

Reference: www.ncbi.com

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presents with history of progressively worsening heavy menstrual bleeding since last 8 months. She has no significant past medical history. She is nulliparous, married since last 3 years and desires to have children in the future. On examination, the uterus is ~12-14 weeks size. USG reveals multiple fibroids, with the largest being ~7 cm in the anterior uterine wall. What is the most appropriate management option for this patient?
questions.solution:
Myomectomy is the preferred surgical treatment for women with symptomatic fibroids who wish to preserve their fertility.

OPTION A: Hysterectomy is definitive but would not be appropriate for a woman desiring future pregnancies.

OPTION B: UAE is less commonly recommended for those who want to conceive. UAE can potentially reduce ovarian reserve, particularly in women over 40, due to collateral damage to the ovarian blood supply. This can lead to premature ovarian failure or reduced ovarian function, affecting fertility.

OPTION D: Endometrial ablation is not effective for large fibroids.

KEY TAKEAWAY:

Myomectomy is the surgical removal of fibroids (myomas) from the uterus, and it is often the treatment of choice for women who wish to preserve fertility. Unlike hysterectomy, which removes the entire uterus, myomectomy leaves the uterus intact, allowing for the possibility of future pregnancy.

It requires careful planning and consideration of the fibroids' size, location, and the patient's overall reproductive goals. Postoperative care and monitoring are crucial to ensure optimal outcomes for future pregnancies.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with heavy menstrual bleeding & dysmenorrhea. She has a 4 cm submucosal fibroid. She and her partner are planning to conceive in the next year. What is the best management option for her fibroid?
questions.solution:
For women who desire future fertility, removal of submucosal fibroids via hysteroscopic myomectomy is often recommended to improve chances of conception and reduce symptoms.

OPTION A: Watchful waiting is not recommended as the woman is symptomatic and also plans to conceive in the upcoming year. Hence intervention is necessary.

OPTION C & D: UAE and GnRH agonists are less favorable due to their negative impact on fertility.

KEY TAKEAWAY:

Hysteroscopic myomectomy is a minimally invasive surgical procedure used to remove submucosal fibroids, which are located within the uterine cavity. This procedure is often considered for women with submucosal fibroids who are experiencing infertility or recurrent pregnancy loss, as submucosal fibroids can interfere with embryo implantation and normal pregnancy progression.

questions.text: A pregnant woman with a history of fibroids presents with severe abdominal pain and tenderness in the second trimester. Ultrasound shows a fibroid with peripheral hypoechoic areas. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Red degeneration (also known as carneous degeneration) is common during pregnancy, especially in the second trimester. It is due to hemorrhage within the fibroid and is characterized by acute pain and tenderness, nausea and vomiting. Management is only conservative, no MTP, myomectomy. It is an aseptic condition: No need for antibiotic.

OPTION A: Calcific degeneration refers to the process where calcium deposits accumulate within a uterine fibroid. This type of degeneration is commonly observed in postmenopausal women due to lower estrogen levels and changes in uterine fibroid tissue over time.

OPTION B: Hyaline degeneration is the most common type of degeneration seen in uterine fibroids, accounting for up to 60% of cases. Most commonly occurs in middle-aged women, typically between the ages of 30 and 50.

OPTION D: Cystic degeneration is a type of fibroid degeneration where the fibroid tissue undergoes liquefaction, leading to the formation of cystic spaces. This form of degeneration is less common, occurring in approximately 4% of fibroids. Commonly seen in perimenopausal and postmenopausal women.

KEY TAKEAWAY:

Red degeneration of fibroid at a glance

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman presents with a complaint of vaginal discharge that is greyish-white and thin and has a fishy odour. She denies itching or significant pelvic pain. On examination, there is no evidence of vulvovaginal inflammation. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Characterized by a fishy odour, greyish-white thin discharge, and no significant inflammation. Caused by garnerella vaginalis.

AMSEL'S CRITERIA: PH>4.5, clue cells+, positive whiff test(amine odor with KOH)

TREATMENT: Metronidazole/clindamycin.

OPTION a) Candidiasis: Typically presents with thick, white, curd-like discharge and significant itching.

OPTION b) Trichomoniasis: Presents with green-yellow frothy discharge, itching, and possibly vulvovaginal inflammation.

OPTION d) Chlamydia infection: Usually asymptomatic or presents with mild symptoms, including cervicitis or pelvic pain, not typically associated with fishy odour.

KEY TAKE AWAY:-

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with complaint of yellow-green, frothy vaginal discharge and intense itching. On speculum examination, a strawberry cervix is noted. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
OPTION a) Bacterial Vaginosis: Typically presents with thin, greyish-white discharge and a fishy odor, not frothy discharge or a strawberry cervix.

OPTION b) Candidiasis: Presents with thick, white, curd-like discharge and intense itching but no frothy discharge or strawberry cervix.

OPTION c) Trichomoniasis: Characterized by yellow-green, frothy discharge, itching, and strawberry cervix (punctate hemorrhages on the cervix).

OPTION d) Chlamydia infection: Often asymptomatic or mild symptoms; not typically associated with frothy discharge or strawberry cervix.

KEY TAKE AWAY:-

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman presents with painful vesicular lesions on her vulva and cervix. She reports that the lesions have been present for the past 5 days and are associated with fever and dysuria. A Tzanck smear of the lesion shows multinucleated giant cells. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of painful vesicular lesions with systemic symptoms and the Tzanck smear showing multinucleated giant cells are characteristic of genital herpes, typically caused by HSV-2.

OPTION A: Candidiasis

Candidiasis typically presents with itching, burning, and thick, white vaginal discharge, but not vesicular lesions. It is caused by the yeast Candida albicans and does not show multinucleated giant cells on a Tzanck smear.

OPTION C: Chancroid

Chancroid is caused by Haemophilus ducreyi and presents with painful ulcers on the genitalia but not vesicular lesions. It does not show multinucleated giant cells on a Tzanck smear.

OPTION D: Syphilis

Syphilis, caused by Treponema pallidum, typically presents with painless chancres in the primary stage, and secondary syphilis can show mucous membrane lesions and rashes. It does not show vesicular lesions or multinucleated giant cells on a Tzanck smear.

KEY TAKE AWAY:-

The clinical presentation of painful vesicular lesions, fever, dysuria, and the Tzanck smear findings of multinucleated giant cells are characteristic of genital herpes (HSV infection).

questions.text: Which of the following is wrongly matched?
questions.solution: Reference: STI/RTI Syndromic Case Management

choices.text: Ensuring her viral load is undetectable

questions.text: A 33-year-old HIV-positive woman is planning to start a family. What is the most important aspect of her preconceptional care to reduce the risk of HIV transmission to her baby?
questions.solution:
The most crucial factor in reducing the risk of mother-to-child transmission of HIV is maintaining an undetectable viral load throughout preconception, pregnancy, and delivery. An undetectable viral load significantly reduces the risk of transmission to the baby to less than 1%.

OPTION A: Initiating a new ART regimen

While being on an effective antiretroviral therapy (ART) is essential, initiating a new ART regimen is not always necessary if the current regimen is effective. The primary goal is to maintain viral suppression. Changing ART without a compelling reason (such as resistance or intolerance) might cause unnecessary complications.

OPTION C: Starting prophylactic antibiotics

Prophylactic antibiotics are used to prevent opportunistic infections in HIV-positive individuals with low CD4 counts but do not reduce the risk of HIV transmission to the baby. This option does not address viral suppression, which is the key to preventing transmission.

OPTION D: Scheduling an elective cesarean section

While elective cesarean delivery may be recommended in specific scenarios (e.g., high viral load near delivery), it is not the most critical aspect of preconception care. If the viral load is undetectable, vaginal delivery is generally safe and does not increase the risk of HIV transmission significantly.

Regular monitoring and adherence to ART are essential for achieving and maintaining this goal.

KEY TAKEAWAY -

Ensuring the viral load remains undetectable is the most critical measure in reducing the risk of HIV transmission from mother to child.

Reference: National Guidelines for HIV Care & Treatment 2021

questions.text: A 28-year-old sexually active woman presents with right upper quadrant pain and mild fever. She has a history of pelvic inflammatory disease (PID). On examination, tenderness is noted in the right upper quadrant. LFTs are normal. The following laparoscopic image is seen. What is the most plausible diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
The differential diagnosis for Fitz-Hugh-Curtis Syndrome primarily includes conditions that present with right upper quadrant pain and systemic symptoms like fever. Distinguishing between these conditions requires a combination of clinical history, physical examination, laboratory tests, and imaging studies.

OPTION A: Liver enzymes are normal. So acute hepatitis can be ruled out.

OPTION B: Acute cholecystitis would not have such adhesions as seen in the laparoscopic image.

OPTION C: Fitz-Hugh-Curtis Syndrome is a perihepatitis associated with pelvic inflammatory disease (PID). It is characterized by the presence of "violin-string" adhesions between the liver capsule and the abdominal wall, as seen in the image. The condition typically presents with right upper quadrant pain, which may be mistaken for gallbladder or liver pathology.

OPTION D: Acute appendicitis will present with right iliac fossa pain & not RUQ pain.

KEY TAKEAWAY:

  • Fitz-Hugh-Curtis Syndrome often presents with right upper quadrant pain that closely resembles gallbladder disease, leading many to initially suspect conditions like cholecystitis.
  • However, this pain is actually caused by adhesions between the liver and the abdominal wall, often called "violin-string" adhesions.
  • These adhesions are a unique and unexpected complication of pelvic inflammatory disease (PID), making this condition an intriguing crossover between gynecology and hepatology!

choices.text: Admit the patient & start empirical intravenous antibiotics
Prescribe oral azithromycin and discharge the patient
Analgesics & antipyretics only would help in this case

questions.text: A 21-year-old sexually active woman presents to the emergency department with lower abdominal pain, fever >38 degree Celsius, and foul-smelling vaginal discharge for the past 5 days. She has a history of multiple sexual partners. On physical examination, there is lower abdominal tenderness and cervical motion tenderness. Laboratory findings reveal a raised TLC & an elevated CRP. NAAT for Chlamydia trachomatis is positive. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this case?
questions.solution:
• The patient presents with signs and symptoms of severe pelvic inflammatory disease (PID), including lower abdominal pain, cervical motion tenderness, and systemic signs of infection (fever and elevated WBC count).
  • The positive NAAT for Chlamydia further supports the diagnosis of PID.
  • Severe PID, especially with systemic symptoms, often requires inpatient management with intravenous antibiotics to ensure rapid and effective treatment, prevent complications like abscess formation, and reduce the risk of infertility.

Option B may be appropriate for mild PID but not in a case with systemic involvement.

Option C (emergency laparotomy) is not indicated unless there is suspicion of complications like tubo-ovarian abscess rupture.

Option D (analgesics & antipyretics) is inadequate for managing PID.

KEY TAKEAWAY:

questions.text: All of the following are risk factors for PID, except:
questions.solution:
Intrauterine contraceptive devices (IUCDs), except for the levonorgestrel-releasing intrauterine system (LNG-IUS), are associated with a slight increased risk of pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) LNG-IUS, which releases levonorgestrel, a hormone that thickens cervical mucus and inhibits sperm penetration, potentially reducing the risk of infection.

OPTION A: Multiple sexual partners are a significant risk factor for Pelvic Inflammatory Disease (PID). They increase the likelihood of exposure to sexually transmitted infections (STIs) like Chlamydia trachomatis and Neisseria gonorrhoeae, which are the primary pathogens responsible for PID. With more partners, the chances of encountering a partner with an untreated or asymptomatic STI are higher, which raises the risk of developing PID. Individuals with multiple partners might not consistently use barrier protection (like condoms), leading to higher transmission rates of STIs.

OPTION C: Lower socioeconomic status leads to a higher risk of Pelvic Inflammatory Disease (PID) primarily due to limited access to healthcare, increased prevalence of risky sexual behaviors, and lack of education and awareness about sexual health.

OPTION D: Younger age (teenage & early 20s) increases the risk of PID due to cervical immaturity, higher rates of sexually transmitted infections (STIs), riskier sexual behaviour, and limited access to healthcare and sexual health education.

KEY TAKEAWAY:

choices.text: Perform peritoneal biopsy and send for AFB culture
Laparoscopic fulguration of whitish nodules on peritoneum

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman is undergoing evaluation for primary infertility. Husband semen analysis is normal. Her menses are scanty & irregular. Her past medical history is significant for a treated episode of pulmonary tuberculosis. Diagnostic laparoscopy reveals multiple small whitish nodules on the peritoneal surfaces, with adhesions and thickened fallopian tubes. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Suggests genital tuberculosis. A peritoneal biopsy with an AFB (Acid-Fast Bacillus) culture is essential to confirm the diagnosis of tuberculosis

OPTION A: Empirical treatment should not be started without confirmation of the diagnosis, especially in the context of infertility where other causes might need to be ruled out.

OPTION B: Assisted reproductive techniques is not the next immediate step; diagnosis should be confirmed first.

OPTION D: While laparoscopy is useful for diagnosis and assessment, fulguration of tubercular deposits is not advised as it does not address the infection itself and could lead to additional complications like increased adhesions, potentially worsening the patient's condition.

KEY TAKEAWAY:

Reference: www.researchgate.com

questions.text: Hysterosalpingogram (HSG) image of a 30-year-old woman shows irregularities and filling defects in the fallopian tubes. The fimbrial ends have a club shaped appearance & the image also reveals a beaded appearance of the tubes. Based on this finding, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Irregular filling defects, clubbed fimbrial ends & beaded appearance of fallopian tubes are commonly seen in cases with Genital TB.

OPTION A: Though HSG is not a primary tool in diagnosis of endometriosis, distorted tubal anatomy & peritubal adhesions are the findings seen.

OPTION C: HSG is not the primary diagnostic tool for adenomyosis. Ultrasound, particularly transvaginal ultrasound, and MRI are much more effective in diagnosing this condition. HSG might show indirect signs of Adenomyosis, like irregular uterine cavity contours, swiss cheese appearance etc. It does not affect the fallopian tubes.

OPTION D: These appear as small, rounded structures filled with contrast, projecting from the fallopian tube. They are indicative of areas where the tubal wall has formed a pouch-like extension. After the procedure, these diverticula may hold onto the contrast medium longer than the rest of the tube, making them more visible on delayed images. If multiple diverticulae are present, beaded appearance may be seen; but clubbed fimbrial ends are seen with genital TB.

KEY TAKEAWAY:

To remember the Hysterosalpingography (HSG) findings associated with genital tuberculosis (TB), the mnemonic 'SCARRED TUBES' can be used

Mnemonic: 'SCARRED TUBES'

  • S - Serrated or Sawtooth appearance of the tubal walls due to irregularities and strictures.
  • C - Caseation: Although not directly visible on HSG, think of calcified lymph nodes or tubal calcifications indicating chronic infection.
  • A - Adhesions: May cause the tubes to appear fixed, distorted, or non-mobile.
  • R - Rigid tubal walls: The fallopian tubes lose their normal smooth and flexible contour.
  • R - Rosenmuller (Tobacco-pouch) sign: A dilated and clubbed ampullary end, resembling a tobacco pouch.
  • E - Endometrial cavity irregularities: Irregularity or obliteration of the uterine cavity due to intrauterine adhesions (Asherman's syndrome).
  • D - Diverticula: Outpouchings seen along the course of the fallopian tubes due to tubal scarring.
  • T - Tubal occlusion: Blockage at the cornual, isthmic, or fimbrial end, leading to non-patency of the tubes.
  • U - Ulceration: Ulcerative lesions might not be visible directly, but severe tubal damage could be inferred from the HSG appearance.
  • B - Beaded appearance: Due to strictures and alternating areas of dilatation, the tube may look beaded.
  • E - Endosalpingitis: Inflammation of the tubal mucosa may cause irregular filling defects.
  • S - Spillage of contrast: There may be delayed or absent contrast spillage into the peritoneal cavity due to tubal occlusion.
